The Company shall indemnify and hold CNET harmless from and against any Losses that CNET may suffer, incur or be subjected to by reason of any legal action, proceeding,




          arbitration or other claim by a third party, whether commenced or           threatened, arising out of or as a result of (a) any breach or alleged           breach by the Company of its representations, warranties or covenants           hereunder; (b) the use by CNET of the Company Marks or any content           provided by the Company to CNET expressly for display in connection           with or as part of the Promotions, including claims of infringement or           misappropriation of intellectual property rights; or (c) the operation           of the Company Site or the offer or sale of the Products by the           Company or through the Company Site.
perturbation.changed_text: The Company shall indemnify and hold CNET harmless from and against any Losses that CNET may suffer, incur or be subjected to by reason of any legal action, proceeding, arbitration or other claim by a third party, whether commenced or threatened, arising out of or as a result of (a) any breach or alleged breach by the Company of its representations, warranties or covenants hereunder; or (b) the use by CNET of the Company Marks or any content provided by the Company to CNET expressly for display in connection with or as part of the Promotions, including claims of infringement or misappropriation of intellectual property rights.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the phrase relating to claims arising from 'the operation of the Company Site or the offer or sale of the Products by the Company or through the Company Site,' this change limits the Company's indemnification obligations. This could violate consumer protection laws that require companies to be responsible for damages resulting from their products or services, regardless of fault (strict liability). California law implies warranties and consumer rights related to product liability and merchantability, which this omission attempts to circumvent.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California implied warranty and product liability laws.

perturbation.original_text: LIMITATION OF DAMAGES. NEITHER PARTY WILL BE LIABLE FOR ANY SPECIAL, INDIRECT, CONSEQUENTIAL OR INCIDENTAL DAMAGES ARISING OUT OF OR RELATED TO THIS AGREEMENT, HOWEVER CAUSED AND ON ANY THEORY OF LIABILITY (INCLUDING NEGLIGENCE), AND EVEN IF SUCH PARTY HAS BEEN ADVISED OF THE POSSIBILITY OF SUCH DAMAGES.
perturbation.changed_text: LIMITATION OF DAMAGES. NEITHER PARTY WILL BE LIABLE FOR ANY INDIRECT, CONSEQUENTIAL OR INCIDENTAL DAMAGES ARISING OUT OF OR RELATED TO THIS AGREEMENT, HOWEVER CAUSED AND ON ANY THEORY OF LIABILITY (INCLUDING NEGLIGENCE), AND EVEN IF SUCH PARTY HAS BEEN ADVISED OF THE POSSIBILITY OF SUCH DAMAGES.
perturbation.explanation: By removing 'SPECIAL' from the types of damages neither party is liable for, it attempts to circumvent California laws that may allow for special damages under certain consumer protection statutes, such as the Consumer Legal Remedies Act. This act protects consumers from unfair or deceptive practices, for which special damages may be recoverable. This creates a potential legal contradiction.

In particular, the           Company agrees that the Company Site will comply with the performance           standards set forth in Exhibit B throughout the Term. perturbation.changed_text: The Company will be responsible for ensuring that each link embedded within an Online Promotion takes the User to the appropriate area within the Company Site. Any failure by the Company to comply with this paragraph will be deemed to be a material breach of this Agreement.
perturbation.explanation: Removing the clause 'and that the Company Site functions with reasonable reliability and in a commercially reasonable manner throughout the Term. In particular, the Company agrees that the Company Site will comply with the performance standards set forth in Exhibit B throughout the Term' weakens the assurance of service to consumers and goes against implied standards in e-commerce. The term has now lost commercially reasonableness. This could contradict consumer protection laws, which require services to be delivered in a reasonably operational way.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California implied warranty of merchantability (UCC 2-314) as it applies to online services.
